segments.text: Hey, podcast listeners.

9th, and Irvine, California on January 30th.
I promise you guys, these are stand-up shows like you've never seen, and I always bring
a special guest straight from the intellectual dark web.
General admission and meet and greet tickets are available at Dave Rubin dot com slash
events.
That's Dave Rubin dot com slash events, and now back to the show.
Joining me today is a biologist, a former professor at Evergreen State, who is now a professor
in exile.
Brett Weinstein, welcome back to the Rubin Report.
Thanks for having me back on.
Professor in exile, my friend.
That's what it says on your Twitter bio, which means it's your most defining characteristic
right now.
That has become the tenor of my life.
I went into the Rubin Report Archives.
They're very much like the Jedi Archives.
I went into the Rubin Report Archives this morning.
You were on this show originally on May 30th, 2017.
That's about a year and a half ago.
It was just as the Evergreen Bruhaha was beginning.
You still were employed at the time, which probably seems like a lifetime ago.
I think first, maybe we should just play a little catch up from then.
Just to be clear, you have been on the show once since then.
You were on with your brother Eric, and we did a little bit about Evergreen in your
life.
I thought first let's just do catch up on what happened, where you're at, where you're
going, and then we're going to do sort of new territory and we're going to cover a lot
of biology and all that.
Great.
So May 30th of 2017 would be exactly one week into the riots, the protest at my classroom
that became relatively famous happened on May 23rd.
One weekend I was sitting in this chair.
That feels like a lifetime ago, doesn't it?
It feels like it for me.
I think less has happened to me, although it's been a pretty busy year and a half.
The transformation of my life and Heather's life in that period has been so dramatic that
it's hard to even relate.
I've never had so much happen in a year.
So for people that don't know anything about the story, and I suspect there's very few
watching this at the moment, can you give me the 90 second recap of what happened?
Can that be done in 90 seconds?
Well, it can be done with carnage.
I'd say I fear this question more than any other because there's so much detail in the
story.
It can't be covered properly.
Give a cliff notes version that basically is an explainer.
Equity and inclusion movement got started on my campus as it is on virtually every campus
and the new president of Evergreen threw fuel on the fire.
He used the division over that issue to accomplish things he could not have accomplished otherwise.
I tried to block his moves to dismantle the excellent part of Evergreen's teaching model,
which Heather and I were using to full effect.
I became effectively enemy number one of this equity and inclusion movement.
They arranged a protest at my classroom.
Very dramatic.
50 students showed up demanding my resignation.
Not a single one of them was a student I had ever encountered.
In any case, they made a terrible error.
They filmed their confrontation with me.
They uploaded it.
I now know to Facebook somebody else in the public picked those videos up and broadcast

That set things in motion where Evergreen started using me as an excuse for its problems.
It blamed me for what happened there for the drop off and enrollment for all sorts

I started engaging with the public about what was taking place at Evergreen, about issues

biology, which people did not initially really understand that that was the focus that I
had not freedom of speech issues now increasingly.
That's what people want to talk to me about.
Although we're going to get to plenty of that because I know that's what your real focus
and passion is and it's sort of funny that now you've been thrust into this.
In effect, you were protesting putting racist policies on campus.
Is that fair to say?
Yes, and this is one of the hardest lessons for people to learn.
People, good people, get the idea that you can spot the right side by certain heuristics.
There's been a historical fact of oppressed people tending to be people of color, etc.
And so people have gotten lazy about recognizing who's in the right.
If you follow a principle to its logical conclusions, in other words, if you're against

And so anyway, yes, it is your principles and adherence to them that gets you in trouble.

Just open the Zeel app and choose your favorite massage style.

An hour later, a licensed massage therapist shows up at your door.

It's like the spa comes to you.
The best part is tip is included so you don't have to dig around for cash when you're done.
Rinse off in your own shower, get back to your day, or go straight to bed.

Zeel, wellness on the way, that Zeel, Z-E-E-L, and now back to the show.
Yeah, okay.
So you then show up in this studio a week after this whole thing goes down.
It was your first public interview about any of this.
What did you think at the time was going to happen by talking about this publicly?
Or what was your hope at least by talking about this publicly?
Well, you know, initially my hope was to expose the foolishness at Evergreen and save the

about this, but for a small number of people, for 4,000 students at a time, Evergreen was

educational advantages before they got to college to have an experience that couldn't
be reproduced anywhere else.
Evergreen's model was so unique that if you ended up in the right classrooms with professors

And you were given incredible freedom as a professor to do what you wanted with these
kids, right?
I believe that the position that Heather and I had was the freest academic position in
the country and maybe on earth.
Wow.
I mean, really more freedom than a tenured professor at Harvard has.
And that was, let's be honest, it was both a blessing and a curse.
If you decided to use that freedom for good, if you decided to figure out how to innovate
structures that didn't exist anywhere else, you could do it and nobody could tell you
not to.
On the other hand, if you decided to take the rest of your career off and teach with one
hand while you dealt with your hobbies, you could also get away with murder.
And so that happened as well.
And there was attention.
Every good professor at Evergreen grumbles about the fact that there are a large number

And the phrase that we typically used in private on the faculty was that Evergreen paid in

But the ability to have a blank canvas and decide what you wanted to teach and in what

It should have leveled with people that it was hiring.
And it should have said, look, this job is not going to make you wealthy, but it can

They just went in on this.

So I would not have been surprised if Evergreen had backed off cynically if they had privately

The fact that that did not happen at all still shocks me and I can't explain it because

He's bonkers, he's one of my favorite words.
He could say it was.
I like bananas too, but bonkers it.
You know, whack-a-doodle something.
Yeah.
But in any case, we have a president who was, I mean, look, he's the Mad King, right?
He's the Mad King and you've got a whole bunch of people standing around accepting

for the college are completely inconsistent with the values that the college was founded

Yeah.
And were they really accepting his authority actually?
Because there are moments in the chaos of this that these videos are posted where he can't

You know what I mean?
He was both puppet and puppeteer.
Yeah.
Okay.

And you know, look, it tells the whole tale.
Once you say what we are doing is about equity.

If you've said that it is for the purpose of racial equity, then a whole section of

What is that?
What is that psychologically?
Do you think?
Oh, I know.
Because I think we're seeing this everywhere now.
This is not just something that's happening at universities anymore.
This is happening all over society.
I wish I could say that it is an error in cognition, that people are seeing it incorrectly.
What I know for sure now, as well as anybody on earth, is that the part of people's minds

Now I'm not looking for sympathy.
I do not have my job anymore, and I miss it.
It was a great job.
However, I've landed on my feet.
I wouldn't trade my position for any other.
I like where I am.
However, first of all, there's not an infinite number of those positions in the world.
So most people who are looking at some sort of an equity and inclusion juggernaut who

Anybody who doesn't have an economic plan B for their family, and I have to say as much

And so I think lots of people are looking ahead and saying, if I stand up and I say

And the problem, the place where I have sympathy for anybody who sees that and says, I don't

And they join not reluctantly, but they become enthusiastic allies of this movement in order

Right.

I mean otherwise you realize that, I mean then you are a sellout.

Well, you know, I do.
So I have to say for, I don't know, a year now, I have had these interactions a couple

Right.
People have people say that.
It's beard.
They're still coming up to you.
Actually, that has reduced it.

I don't know.

Oh man, I see.
Yeah.
I could go on the land.

Yeah.

There are two things to say on this front.

There are a lot of adaptations that do not map well onto the individual.
If you look at the individual and you say, well, why would the person behave this way?

Sometimes if you look at something larger than the individual and it's not the group,

So what I would say is an individual who can't sleep if they're not doing the right thing
